CATALOGUE

Of the Library of the

North China Branch
Royal Asiatic Society

Contained in the

SOCIETY'S BUILDING

No. 5 Museum Road,
Shanghai.
PREFACE
TO THE FOURTH EDITION.

The first Edition of the Catalogue of the library of the N. C. B. Royal Asiatic Society was prepared by Mr. Henri Cordier, and in the preface he referred to Mr. Wylie's library of 718 volumes and pamphlets which, added to the other volumes already in the possession of the Society, formed a collection of standard works on the East numbering about 1,300 volumes.

Since, in 1894, Mr. Joseph Haas completed the third edition of the library catalogue there has been but one issue of a list of additions thereto, namely that compiled in 1899, by Herr Emil Fischer and published in Vol. XXX of the Journal. Members of the Society and the reading public generally, have, therefore, since then, been in ignorance of much that the library contains.

In 1907 after careful deliberation, the Council decided that a new catalogue be prepared—that all the books in the library, instead of being kept, as heretofore apart as a "Museum Section," China Section, etc. should be included in the same Catalogue, and finally, that one of the most modern systems of classification should be adopted.

Upon the strong recommendation of Mr. Bolton of the Athenæum, Boston, U.S.A., who rendered invaluable aid, it was decided to make a "dictionary catalogue" on cards, classifying according to the Dewey Decimal Classification and Index, used in conjunction with the Cutter Author Numbers. It may be well to give in the words of the author a short explanation of this classification.

"The field of knowledge is divided into nine main classes, and these are numbered by the digits 1 to 9—Encyclopaedias, etc., so general in character as to belong to no one of these classes are marked nought and form a tenth class. Each class is similarly separated into 9 divisions, divisions are similarly divided into 9 sections, and the process is repeated as often as is necessary. The books on the shelves are arranged in simple numerical order, and since each subject has a definite number it follows that all books on any subject must stand together."

The Cutter Numbers for their part provide each book with a Shelf Number in addition to its Class Number.

A dictionary catalogue was decided upon as being that which would prove of most service to students. Therein works appear, not only under their author's name, their title, but also under the subject, or subjects, to which they refer. For instance, M. Cordier's Edition of Yule's Marco Polo will be found under Cordier, Yule, Polo, Travel, Asia (travels in). The student, desirous of knowing what books on any particular subject the library can place at his disposal has but to turn that subject up. "Inscriptions" "Birds" "Language" "Geology" "History" etc., as the case may be. Under each heading he will find a list of the works thereon.

In 1908 this catalogue was completed and the books were re-shelved. During this work the old catalogue was in continual use and but few changes were found necessary, in the actual classification,—while the ample and studious notes, of my predecessors, were carefully preserved. Copies of the old catalogue being dissected and the note on each work, being pasted on to the title and reference cards of the new Catalogue.

While the advantages of this card system, its possibility of infinite expansion, its comprehensiveness, etc., are obvious, the disadvantages are no less so. To those members of the Society who do not live in Shanghai the complete contents of the library were as unknown as ever, and even for those on the spot, a journey to the library itself, was necessary, to discover these same contents.
It was therefore decided to print, and issue in book form, a classified catalogue arranged according to subjects. This of necessity, has been done in a manner as abbreviated as possible. Each work is mentioned, it is true, but only once, and then in the class to which it belongs. Its title is where possible condensed—its author is shorn of all titles and degrees—in fact the printed catalogue is but a skeleton of the card catalogue which may be consulted in the library itself.

Such as it is however it will serve to bring to the notice of all our friends not only what the library contains, but what it lacks. Many of the remarks of M. Cordier and M. Haas apply to-day as they did 15 years ago; but judging by the generous and immediate response that has met all my requests for assistance during this period of re-organization, I feel that it is only through forgetfulness that the library is ever neglected—and can but hope that this booklet may serve as a silent reminder, to those who have aught to give, that an honoured place for the fruit of their labours is prepared on the library shelves of the N.C.B.R.A.S.

Florence Wheelock Ayscough.
Hon. Librarian.

July 24th, 1909.
PREFACE TO FIFTH EDITION.

Since the last edition of the Catalogue was printed in 1909 the growth of the library has been slow but steady, and the number of people using it not only in Shanghai but also in the interior of China have greatly increased.

It still suffers from the forgetfulness,—not the willing neglect—of authors. Refusals to requests for books are rare, but unfortunately unsolicited presentations are not as numerous as might be wished.

May the hope be treasured that in the preface to the sixth edition no such remark need be made.

Florence Wheelock Ayscough.

March, 1921.
LIBRARY RULES

I.—The Library is open daily.

II.—The circulation of the books is under the control of the Council of the Society.

III.—Members of the Society not resident in Shanghai may have books sent to their address by making arrangements for delivery satisfactory to the Hon. Librarian.

IV.—Members are not to have more than three works at a time, nor keep any books longer than 21 days.

V.—Library privileges are not transferable. Members may not lend the books taken out in their names to persons other than those resident in their own homes.

VI.—Works of reference and certain rare and valuable books are not to be taken out of the Library building, nor are Scientific Journals and Periodicals circulated until the volumes are completed and bound.

VII.—When the time allowed for the perusal of a work has expired, it must be returned to the Library within 24 hours after the receipt of a notice that it is required at the Library, or a fine of half-a-dollar per day will be exacted.

VIII.—Members are responsible for the careful preservation and safe return of all books issued to them, and they will be required to make good any loss or damage in these respects.

IX.—If a work or any portion of it should be lost or damaged, defaced by writing or otherwise injured, the Member to whom it was issued will be responsible for its whole cost, whatever that may be.

X.—The infraction of any of these Rules will be followed by the withdrawal from a Member of his privilege of taking books out of the Library, and the payment of all penalties or other amounts due will be enforced in any way that may be thought fit.

XI.—The Council of the North China Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society may at any time call in all books and may cease to issue them for such periods as the interests of the Society may require.

For the purpose of Rules IV and VII each volume of the Transactions of any Learned Society or similar publication shall be counted as one work, but under Rule IX a Member may be called upon to replace a whole series unless the volumes can be obtained separately.
